content.title: Foreword
content.description:
This Technical Report has been produced by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP).
The contents of the present document are subject to continuing work within the TSG and may change following formal TSG approval. Should the TSG modify the contents of the present document, it will be re-released by the TSG with an identifying change of release date and an increase in version number as follows:
Version x.y.z
where:
x	the first digit:
1	presented to TSG for information;
2	presented to TSG for approval;
3	or greater indicates TSG approved document under change control.
y	the second digit is incremented for all changes of substance, i.e. technical enhancements, corrections, updates, etc.
z	the third digit is incremented when editorial only changes have been incorporated in the document.
In the present document, modal verbs have the following meanings:
shall	indicates a mandatory requirement to do something
shall not	indicates an interdiction (prohibition) to do something
The constructions "shall" and "shall not" are confined to the context of normative provisions, and do not appear in Technical Reports.
The constructions "must" and "must not" are not used as substitutes for "shall" and "shall not". Their use is avoided insofar as possible, and they are not used in a normative context except in a direct citation from an external, referenced, non-3GPP document, or so as to maintain continuity of style when extending or modifying the provisions of such a referenced document.
should	indicates a recommendation to do something
should not	indicates a recommendation not to do something
may	indicates permission to do something
need not	indicates permission not to do something
The construction "may not" is ambiguous and is not used in normative elements. The unambiguous constructions "might not" or "shall not" are used instead, depending upon the meaning intended.
can	indicates that something is possible
cannot	indicates that something is impossible
The constructions "can" and "cannot" are not substitutes for "may" and "need not".
will	indicates that something is certain or expected to happen as a result of action taken by an agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
will not	indicates that something is certain or expected not to happen as a result of action taken by an agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
might	indicates a likelihood that something will happen as a result of action taken by some agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
might not	indicates a likelihood that something will not happen as a result of action taken by some agency the behaviour of which is outside the scope of the present document
In addition:
is	(or any other verb in the indicative mood) indicates a statement of fact
is not	(or any other negative verb in the indicative mood) indicates a statement of fact
The constructions "is" and "is not" do not indicate requirements.

content.title: 1	Scope
content.description: The present document is a Technique Report for Measurements of Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) Over-the-Air (OTA) performance of User Equipment (UE). It includes analysis and measurement results of MIMO OTA in Frequency Range 1 and Frequency Range 2, such as verification of channel models, lab alignment activities, etc..

content.title: 2	References
content.description:
The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present document.
-	References are either specific (identified by date of publication, edition number, version number, etc.) or non-specific.
-	For a specific reference, subsequent revisions do not apply.
-	For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies. In the case of a reference to a 3GPP document (including a GSM document), a non-specific reference implicitly refers to the latest version of that document in the same Release as the present document.
[1]	3GPP TR 21.905: "Vocabulary for 3GPP Specifications".
[2]	3GPP TR 38.151: “NR; Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) Over-the-Air (OTA) performance requirements for NR UEs”.
[3]	3GPP TR 38.827: “Study on radiated metrics and test methodology for the verification of multi-antenna reception performance of NR User Equipment (UE)”.
[4]	3GPP TS 38.101-1: "NR; User Equipment (UE) radio transmission and reception; Part 1: Range 1 Standalone"
[5]	3GPP TS 38.101-2: "NR; User Equipment (UE) radio transmission and reception; Part 2: Range 2 Standalone"

content.title: 3	Definitions of terms, symbols and abbreviations

subsections.title: 3.1	Terms
subsections.text_content:
For the purposes of the present document, the terms given in TR 21.905 [1] and the following apply. A term defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition of the same term, if any, in TR 21.905 [1].
FS: UE used in a free space configuration.
Handheld UE: A UE intended to be used in hand held scenario.
MIMO Average Spherical Coverage: An averaged sensitivity of best 18 FR2 MIMO OTA sensitivity values within the 3D sphere with constant-density points for PC3 device.
Primary mechanical mode: The mode that is most often used for a specific user scenario. Every terminal has at least one primary mechanical mode, if multiple modes are supported, different primary mechanical modes may be applicable for different user scenarios, e.g., different primary mechanical modes for Free Space and Hand phantom usage for the same UE.
PSP (PAS Similarity Percentage):  The similarity of the PAS produced by the OTA system and the reference PAS, which is presented by the Total Variation Distance (TVD) of power angular spectrum (PAS). PSP is defined as (1-TVD)*100%. PSP=100% denotes full similarity and PSP=0% denotes full dissimilarity..

subsections.title: 4.1	Device types
subsections.text_content: The present technical report covers the smartphone device type.

subsections.title: 4.2	Testing configuration
subsections.text_content: The present technical report covers the free space (FS) testing configuration.

subsections.title: 4.3	Testing Bands
subsections.text_content: The present technical report covers both FR1 and FR2 operating bands. FR1 operating bands are defined in TS 38.101-1 [4] and FR2 operating bands are defined in TS 38.101-2 [5]. NSA band combinations are defined in TS 38.101-3 [6]. E-UTRA is designed to operate in operating bands defined in TS 36.101 [8].

subsections.title: 5.1	General
subsections.text_content: The measurements in the present technical report are based on the test methodology defined in 3GPP TS 38.151 [2] and 3GPP TR 38.827 [3].

subsections.title: 5.2	Measurement setup for FR1 MIMO OTA
subsections.text_content: The multi-probe anechoic chamber (MPAC) test method is the reference methodology for FR NR MIMO OTA testing, the measurement setup and test procedure are defined in TS 38.151 [2].

subsections.title: 5.3	Measurement setup for FR2 MIMO OTA
subsections.text_content: The 3D MPAC test method is the reference methodology for FR2 NR MIMO OTA testing, the measurement setup and test procedure are defined in TS 38.151 [2].

subsections.title: 6.1	General
subsections.text_content: This clause describes the FR1 and FR2 MIMO OTA channel model validation measurements. The purpose of channel model validation is to ensure that the channel models are correctly implemented and hence capable of generating the propagation environment, as described by the model, within the test zone.

subsections.title: 6.2	Verification of Channel Model implementation of FR1

subsubsections.title: 6.2.1	Framework
subsubsections.text_content:
This clause describes how to proceed Channel Model Validation for FR1 MIMO OTA with MPAC system.
-	The channel model validation measurements shall be performed according to the procedures in Annex C.3 of TS 38.151, including:
-	Power Delay Profile (PDP)
-	Doppler/Temporal correlation
-	Spatial correlation
-	Cross-polarization
-	Power validation
-	Channel model: FR1 UMa CDL-C and UMi CDL-C, as specified in Annex C.1 of TS 38.151
-	Test frequency: as specified in Tables C.3.1-1 and C.3.1-2 of TS 38.151
-	Pass/fail limits: as defined in Annex C.4 of TS 38.151

Figure 6.2.2.1-7 presents the PDP (Power Delay Profile) measurement results for a CDL-C (Cellular Downlink Load Control) scenario in UMi (Urban Micro) band n28, with beam 1. The graph displays the PDP in decibels (dB) over time in milliseconds (ms), illustrating the signal strength and delay characteristics of the network. The results are crucial for optimizing the network's performance and ensuring reliable communication.
Figure 6.2.2.1-7: Lab 1: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at Band n28, beam 1

The figure displays the path loss, delay spread, and angle spread across different distances, providing insights into the performance of the cellular network in the urban micro-cell scenario. The results are crucial for optimizing the network's coverage and capacity, ensuring seamless connectivity for users in the urban micro-cell environment.
Figure 6.2.2.1-8: Lab 2: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at Band n28, beam 1
Figure 6.2.2.1-9 presents the PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at Band n28, beam 1. The graph displays the received power in dBm on the vertical axis against the angle in degrees on the horizontal axis. The results show a clear peak at 0 degrees, indicating the strongest signal reception occurs when the antenna is aligned directly with the transmitter. The graph also reveals a gradual decrease in power as the angle increases, with minimal variation across the 9 beams tested. This information is crucial for optimizing the antenna's orientation to maximize signal strength and minimize interference.
Figure 6.2.2.1-9: Lab 4: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at Band n28, beam 1

The graph also reveals a gradual decrease in power as the angle increases, with minimal variation across the 10-degree range. This information is crucial for optimizing the antenna's orientation to maximize signal strength and coverage in the given environment.
Figure 6.2.2.1-10: Lab 5: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at Band n28, beam 1

The figure displays the path loss, log-normal shadowing, and angle-of-arrival (AOA) distributions for the given scenario. The path loss is represented by the blue line, while the log-normal shadowing is depicted by the red line. The AOA distributions are shown by the green line. The figure also includes a legend to help interpret the different lines. The results indicate the performance of the CDL-C UMi system at Band n28, beam 1, providing valuable insights for network optimization and planning.
Figure 6.2.2.1-11: Lab 6: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at Band n28, beam 1

The figure displays the path loss, log-normal shadowing, and small-scale fading characteristics of the signal as it travels through the urban micro-cellular (UMi) environment. The results are presented in a polar coordinate system, with the horizontal axis representing the distance in meters and the vertical axis representing the signal strength in decibels (dB). The figure shows that the path loss increases with distance, and the log-normal shadowing and small-scale fading affect the signal strength at different distances. The figure is useful for understanding the performance of CDL-C UMi networks in urban environments and for optimizing the network parameters.

The data points are color-coded, with blue representing lower signal strength and red indicating stronger signals. This information is crucial for network optimization and planning, as it helps in identifying areas of potential congestion and adjusting the network's resource allocation accordingly.

The results are presented in a clear and concise manner, allowing for easy interpretation of the signal's behavior in a real-world scenario.

subsections.title: 6.3	Verification of Channel Model implementation of FR2

subsubsections.title: 6.3.1	Framework
subsubsections.text_content:
This clause describes how to proceed Channel Model Validation for FR2 MIMO OTA with 3D-MPAC system.
1.	The channel model validation measurements shall be performed as described in Annex D.3 of TS 38.151, including:
-	Power delay profile (PDP)
-	Doppler/Temporal correlation
-	PAS similarity percentage (PSP)
-	Cross-polarization
-	Power validation
2.	Channel model: FR2 UMi CDL-C, as specified in Annex D.1 of TS 38.151
3.	Test frequency: as specified in Tables D.3.1-1 of TS 38.151
4.	Pass/fail limits: as defined in Annex D.2 of TS 38.151

subsubsections.title: 6.3.2	Channel Model Validation Results
subsubsections.text_content:
This clause presents channel model validation results from different labs with different types of equipment and setup vendors. All the validation results are included for comparison. Table 6.3.2-1 lists equipment and setup vendors of different labs.
Table 6.3.2-1: Equipment and setup vendors of different labs (FR2)

The PDP measurement results of UMi CDL-C for bands n261/28GHz are presented in Figures 6.3.2.1-1~6.

Figure 6.3.2.1-1 presents the PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at 28GHz in a laboratory setting. The figure illustrates the distribution of the Path-Delay Spread (PDS) across different paths, with the x-axis representing the number of paths and the y-axis representing the PDS value. The results show that the PDS is relatively low for the first few paths, indicating that the signal experiences minimal delay and loss. However, as the number of paths increases, the PDS also increases, suggesting that the signal's performance degrades with more path diversity. This information is crucial for understanding the performance of CDL-C UMi at 28GHz and optimizing the network configuration.
Figure 6.3.2.1-1: Lab A: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at 28GHz
Figure 6.3.2.1-2 presents the PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261 in a laboratory setting. The figure illustrates the path loss, shadowing, and penetration loss characteristics of the signal in a typical urban microcellular environment. The results are presented in a polar coordinate system, with the horizontal axis representing the distance from the transmitter (Tx) and the vertical axis representing the received power (Rx). The data points are color-coded to distinguish between different scenarios, such as different carrier frequencies or antenna configurations. The figure highlights the importance of understanding these factors in designing and optimizing cellular networks for improved coverage and capacity.
Figure 6.3.2.1-2: Lab B: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.1-3 presents the measurement results of a PDP (Physical Layer Data Unit Profile) for CDL-C UMi (Unlicensed Mobile Access) at band n261. The graph displays the PDP parameters, including the maximum and minimum received power levels, as well as the average and peak delay spread. The results are crucial for understanding the performance of CDL-C UMi in the n261 band and for optimizing the network's coverage and capacity.
Figure 6.3.2.1-3: Lab C: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.1-4 presents the measurement results of a PDP (Physical Layer Data Unit Profile) for CDL-C UMi (Unlicensed Mobile Access) at band n261. The graph displays the PDP parameters, including the maximum and minimum received power, as well as the average and peak delay spread. The results are presented in a clear and concise manner, allowing for an analysis of the signal quality and performance in the given frequency band. The figure highlights the importance of PDP measurements in assessing the suitability of unlicensed spectrum for mobile communications.
Figure 6.3.2.1-4: Lab D: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.1-5 Lab E presents the PDP (Power Delay Profile) measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261. The graph displays the PDP in dB (decibels) versus delay spread in microseconds, with the x-axis representing delay spread and the y-axis representing PDP in dB. The results show a clear peak in PDP at a delay spread of approximately 100 microseconds, indicating the strongest signal reception at this point. The graph also indicates the presence of multiple paths, with the strongest path having a PDP of approximately -90 dB. This information is crucial for optimizing the network's performance and ensuring reliable communication.
Figure 6.3.2.1-5 Lab E: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.1-6 Lab F presents the measurement results of PDP (Power Delay Profile) for CDL-C UMi (Cellular Downlink Control Channel User Equipment) at a 28GHz frequency. The graph displays the PDP in dB (decibels) versus delay spread in microseconds, illustrating the signal's behavior in terms of delay and attenuation. The results are crucial for understanding the performance of the 28GHz frequency band in urban microcellular environments, which is characterized by buildings and other obstacles that can cause signal reflections and delays. The data points and trend lines provide insights into the signal's propagation characteristics, which are essential for optimizing network planning and deployment.
Figure 6.3.2.1-6 Lab F: PDP measurement results for CDL-C UMi at 28GHz

The Doppler measurement results of UMi CDL-C for bands n261/28GHz are presented in Figures 6.3.2.2-1~6.
Figure 6.3.2.2-1 presents a detailed analysis of Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261. The graph displays the frequency shift (s) over time (t), revealing the impact of mobile speed on signal propagation. The results are presented in a clear, color-coded format, with different lines representing various speeds. The figure emphasizes the importance of accurate Doppler measurements in maintaining reliable communication in dynamic environments.
Figure 6.3.2.2-1: Lab A: Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.2-2 illustrates the Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261, showcasing the frequency shifts observed as a mobile user moves through the coverage area. The graph displays the frequency shift (FS) on the y-axis, measured in Hz, and the distance (d) covered on the x-axis, measured in meters. The results reveal a clear relationship between the frequency shift and the distance covered, with a consistent pattern of increase as the user moves further away from the base station. This information is crucial for optimizing network performance and ensuring seamless connectivity for mobile users.
Figure 6.3.2.2-2: Lab B: Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.2-3 presents a detailed analysis of Doppler measurement results for a CDL-C UMi scenario at 28GHz. The figure illustrates the frequency shifts observed as the mobile station (MS) moves relative to the base station (BS) in a cluttered urban microcell (UMi) environment. The Doppler shift values are plotted against the angle of arrival (AOA) and the distance between the MS and BS. The results highlight the impact of path loss, shadowing, and multipath propagation on the frequency shift, providing valuable insights for optimizing 5G network performance in challenging urban scenarios.
Figure 6.3.2.2-3: Lab C: Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at 28GHz
Figure 6.3.2.2-4 presents a detailed analysis of Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261. The graph displays the frequency shift (FS) in megahertz (MHz) on the y-axis, while the x-axis represents the time in milliseconds (ms). The results are presented in a scatter plot format, with individual data points representing the frequency shift observed at different time intervals. The data points are color-coded to distinguish between different measurement conditions or parameters. The trend lines and shaded areas around the data points provide a visual representation of the variability and consistency of the Doppler measurements. This figure is essential for understanding the performance and stability of the CDL-C UMi network at the specified band and for identifying any potential issues or areas for improvement in the network's signal processing and transmission capabilities.
Figure 6.3.2.2-4: Lab D: Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.2-5 presents a detailed analysis of Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261. The graph displays the frequency shift (FS) in megahertz (MHz) on the y-axis, while the x-axis represents the time in milliseconds (ms). The results are categorized into different scenarios, with each scenario marked by a distinct line style. The Doppler measurements are crucial for understanding the propagation characteristics of the signal in the given environment. The figure emphasizes the importance of accurate Doppler measurements in wireless communication systems, particularly in the context of carrier-grade local area networks (CDL-C UMi) operating at the n261 band.
Figure 6.3.2.2-5: Lab E: Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at band n261
Figure 6.3.2.2-6 presents a detailed analysis of Doppler measurement results for a CDL-C UMi scenario at 28GHz. The figure illustrates the frequency offset (Δf) in megahertz (MHz) on the vertical axis and the Doppler shift (Δf_D) in MHz on the horizontal axis. The data points are represented by various shapes and colors, each corresponding to a specific time instance. The results show a clear trend of frequency offset and Doppler shift over time, providing valuable insights into the performance of the 28GHz CDL-C UMi system under different conditions.
Figure 6.3.2.2-6: Lab F: Doppler measurement results for CDL-C UMi at 28GHz

The PAS measurement results of UMi CDL-C for band n261/28GHz are presented in Figures 6.3.2.3-1~6. The corresponding PSP values are summarized in Table 6.3.2.3-1.
Figure 6.3.2.3-1 presents a laboratory measurement result for CDL-C UMi at band n261, showcasing the performance of the Universal Mobile Telecommunications System (UMTS) in a specific scenario. The figure displays the Signal-to-Interference Ratio (SIR) and Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) values, which are crucial metrics for evaluating the quality of a cellular network. The SIR measures the strength of the desired signal relative to the interference, while the SNR quantifies the strength of the signal relative to the noise. The results are presented in a bar chart format, with the SIR and SNR values on the y-axis and the frequency bands on the x-axis. The chart reveals that the CDL-C UMi network achieves a high SIR and SNR across all tested frequency bands, indicating a robust and reliable communication environment.

content.title: 7	Lab alignment of FR1 MIMO OTA

subsections.title: 7.1	General
subsections.text_content: To establish valid and trustable measurement data pools for defining FR1 MIMO OTA requirements, lab alignment campaigns are required before measurement campaign for ensuring there is no unexpected deviations among labs. 3GPP RAN4 performed a lab alignment campaign for bands > 1GHz during Rel-17, and a lab alignment campaign for bands < 1GHz during Rel-18.

subsections.title: 7.2	Noise impact in MPAC on MIMO performance
subsections.text_content:
This clause includes analysis and experimental measurement results of the impact of noise in MPAC on FR1 MIMO OTA performance.
During Rel-18, several companies studied the impact of noise in MPAC on FR1 MIMO OTA performance, conducted experiments, and obtained similar observations. It was found that by adding suitable attenuators after the amplifiers in MPAC system, the impact of noise can be eliminated and the MIMO OTA measurement results can be corrected, as shown in Figure 7.2-1.
Figure 7.2-1 illustrates the measurement setup for correcting FR1 MIMO OTA test results with MPAC. The setup includes a transmitter (TX) and a receiver (RX) with multiple antennas, as well as a measurement antenna (MPAC) for accurate signal reception. The FR1 stands for Frequency Division Duplexing, a technique used in 4G and 5G networks for efficient data transmission. The MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple Output) technology enhances signal quality by transmitting and receiving data through multiple antennas at the same time. The MPAC is crucial for precise signal reception, ensuring that the test results are accurate and reliable. The setup demonstrates the importance of proper measurement techniques in evaluating the performance of FR1 MIMO systems.
Figure 7.2-1: Measurement setup for correcting FR1 MIMO OTA test results with MPAC
The measurement results (12 orientations average in FS DMP mode) at bands n28 (780.5MHz) and n41 (2593MHz) obtained by Lab 1 are show in Figure 7.2-2. The same DUT were measured with different attenuation values. It can be observed that, as the attenuation value increases, the measurement results first get better and then become stable. At the lower frequency, the effect of the attenuation value is more obvious, and it requires a lager attenuation to make the measurement results stable. The reason is that at lower frequency, the path loss from the amplifier output to the chamber centre is smaller, and when the amplifier noise arrives at the chamber centre, it has higher power than that at higher frequency.
Adding attenuators after the amplifiers can reduce the noise and make it neglectable for FR1 MIMO OTA testing. A suitable attenuation value can be selected, e.g., for band n28, the measurement results with 20dB-attenuation and 30dB-attenuation are almost the same, but the measurement result with 10dB-attenuation is worse, which means 20dB-attenuation is enough for band n28 in Lab 1’s MPAC system.
The given telecommunication figure illustrates two distinct frequency bands, n28 and n41, which are part of the 5G spectrum. Band n28 operates at a frequency of 780.5MHz, while band n41 operates at a higher frequency of 2593MHz. The figure provides a visual representation of how these bands are utilized in 5G networks, highlighting their unique characteristics and how they contribute to the overall performance and efficiency of the system. The figure is a valuable resource for understanding the complex interplay between different frequency bands in 5G technology.   The given telecommunication figure (a) and (b) provides a detailed visual representation of two distinct frequency bands, n28 and n41, which are part of the 5G spectrum. Band n28 operates at a frequency of 780.5MHz, while band n41 operates at a higher frequency of 2593MHz. The figure illustrates how these bands are utilized in 5G networks, highlighting their unique characteristics and how they contribute to the overall performance and efficiency of the system. The figure is a valuable resource for understanding the complex interplay between different frequency bands in 5G technology.
(a) Band n28 (780.5MHz)                                                  (b) Band n41 (2593MHz)
Figure 7.2-2: Measured MIMO OTA performance with different attenuation values (in Lab 1)

Figures 7.2-3 and 7.2-4 present the measurement results at band n28 (780.5MHz) from Lab 2 and Lab 4. Similar phenomenon can be observed.
Figure 7.2-3 illustrates the measured performance of multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) over-the-air (OTA) testing at band n28 (780.5MHz) with varying attenuation values in a laboratory setting. The graph displays the relationship between signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and the number of antennas (M) used in the MIMO system. The results show that as the number of antennas increases, the SNR also increases, indicating improved performance. The figure also highlights the impact of different attenuation values on the system's ability to maintain a high SNR, with lower attenuation values generally resulting in better performance. The data presented in the figure is crucial for optimizing MIMO systems and understanding the trade-offs between system complexity and performance.
Figure 7.2-3: Measured MIMO OTA performance at band n28 (780.5MHz)  with different attenuation values (in Lab 2)
Figure 7.2-4 illustrates the measured performance of multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) over-the-air (OTA) testing at band n28 (780.5MHz) with varying attenuation values in a laboratory setting. The graph displays the relationship between signal strength and attenuation, with different data points representing tests conducted with various antenna configurations and distances. The results highlight the impact of attenuation on signal quality and the effectiveness of different antenna setups in mitigating signal loss. The figure is crucial for understanding the performance trade-offs in designing MIMO systems for different operational conditions.
Figure 7.2-4: Measured MIMO OTA performance at band n28  (780.5MHz) with different attenuation values (in Lab 4)
Table 7.2-1 presents the measurement results at band n28 (780.5MHz) from Lab 6, RS EPRE difference between FR1 MIMO OTA system with and without 10dB attenuators are listed.
Table 7.2-1: Measured RS EPRE difference between FR1 MIMO OTA system with and without 10dB attenuators at band n28  (780.5MHz) in Lab 6

Based on the observations, RAN4 reached the following agreements:
-	Labs should first exclude the impact of noise before performing MIMO OTA measurements, especially for frequency bands <1GHz.
-	Perform a low-band lab alignment activity at Band n28, to cross-validate the measurement results from different labs and ensure the validity of the data pool for requirements definition.

subsections.title: 7.3	Lab alignment campaign for frequency bands > 1GHz

subsubsections.title: 7.3.1	Framework
subsubsections.text_content:
This clause defines the working procedure on how to proceed the lab alignment campaign for frequency bands > 1GHz.
Labs/companies volunteer to participate in the performance requirement part shall complete the lab alignment measurements and system validation measurements, results should be submitted to RAN4 for review.
Using the testing conditions as defined in TS38.151.
The test bands for lab alignment are n41 and n78. Three performance alignment devices (PADs) for each band should be tested to ensure the alignment of measurement results.
TRMS value in SA mode will be used for alignment comparison.
The reference value of each PAD should be the average of the PAD measurement results submitted on or before 12:00 UTC 30th April 2022, based on the condition at least 3 labs’ results collected. Submission with measurement data after 12:00 UTC 30th April can be considered for lab alignment, but will not change the reference TRMS value.
The acceptance criteria for declaring alignment should be defined based on the preliminary MU value of MPAC system. The detailed criteria for accepting the outcome of the lab alignment activity are listed in Table 7.3.3-1.
Table 7.3.3-1: Requirements for lab alignment results (FR1 MIMO OTA)

Note:
-	The PAD measurement results shall NOT be shared to anyone before submitting to RAN4 meetings or sharing in the NR MIMO OTA reflector. Comparison and alignment analyses should only be done in RAN4 meetings.
-	Three PADs for each band are selected. Labs should submit PAD measurements results in an anonymous approach, i.e., the PADs for each band should be marked as PAD_1, PAD_2, and PAD_3, respectively. The mapping between the codename PAD_n and the actual PAD shall only be known among the labs participated in the alignment activity, and shall NOT be disclosed to any other companies.

tables.description: Table 7.3.3-1: Requirements for lab alignment results (FR1 MIMO OTA)

subsubsections.title: 7.3.2	Measurement results
subsubsections.text_content:
RAN4 carried out the lab alignment campaign for frequency bands > 1GHz during Rel-17. Considering the test burden and urgent timeline, RAN4 decided to select three smartphones (named as PADs, Performance Alignment Devices) as reference DUTs, and select two bands, n41 and n78, to perform FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment activity for frequencies bands > 1GHz.
There are 6 test labs participated in the lab alignment campaign, the reference value of each PAD at each band is derived based on linear average (with dBm) of PAD measurement results submitted by all labs. The summary of the lab alignment results is shown in Table 7.3.2-1 and Figure 7.3.2-1. The TRMS offset between each measurement result and reference value of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment is shown in Table 7.3.2-2 and Figure 7.3.2-1.
Table 7.3.2-1: Summary of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment results for bands > 1GHz

Table 7.3.2-2: FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment outcome - TRMS offset (for bands > 1GHz)

Figure 7.3.2-1 presents the measurement results of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment for bands greater than 1GHz. The graph displays the performance of various antenna configurations, with the x-axis representing frequency bands and the y-axis indicating the gain in decibels (dB). The results show that the 8x8 MIMO configuration achieves the highest gain across all tested bands, followed by the 4x4 and 2x2 configurations. The data points are plotted with error bars, indicating the variability in the measurements. The figure highlights the importance of proper antenna alignment and configuration for maximizing signal strength and reducing interference in millimeter-wave communications.
Figure 7.3.2-1: Measurement results of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment for bands > 1GHz
Figure 7.3.2-2 illustrates the deviation between each measurement result and the reference value of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment for bands greater than 1GHz. The figure shows the alignment of the antenna elements in a multi-input, multi-output (MIMO) over-the-air (OTA) laboratory setup. The deviation is measured in decibels (dB) and represents the difference between the actual and expected performance of the system. The figure highlights the importance of precise alignment in achieving optimal performance in the FR1 band, which is crucial for 5G technology.
Figure 7.3.2-2: Deviation between each measurement result and reference value of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment for bands > 1GHz

tables.description: Table 7.3.2-1: Summary of FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment results for bands > 1GHz
Table 7.3.2-2: FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment outcome - TRMS offset (for bands > 1GHz)

subsubsections.title: 7.3.3	Pass/fail limits
subsubsections.text_content:
Based on the preliminary MU assessment of FR1 MPAC system in Annex A.2.5 of TS 38.151, and lab alignment measurement results in Clause 7.3.2, RAN4 decided the final pass/fail limits for FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment activity for bands > 1GHz as 0.75* preliminary MU, i.e.,
-	< 3GHz: 2.25 dB
-	> 3GHz: 2.55 dB

subsubsections.title: 7.3.4	Conclusion
subsubsections.text_content: RAN4 concluded the successful FR1 MIMO OTA lab alignment activity for bands > 1GHz, all the 6 test labs are aligned. FR1 MIMO OTA performance requirements for bands > 1GHz are specified based on the measurement results submitted by the above aligned test labs.

subsections.title: 7.4	Lab alignment campaign for frequency bands < 1GHz

subsubsections.title: 7.4.1	Framework
subsubsections.text_content:
This clause defines the working procedure on how to proceed the lab alignment campaign for frequency bands < 1GHz.
1.	Test labs are invited to participate in the lab alignment activity, the following conditions should be fulfilled:
-	At least 3 participating labs are required.
-	Participating labs shall complete channel model validation.
-	Participating labs should have sufficient test resource to provide on-time measurement results without delay.
-	Participating labs should first examine and exclude the impact of noise before submitting PAD measurement results.
2.	Test methodology:
-	Test plan: 3GPP TS 38.151
-	Test system: MPAC
3.	Test cases for Lab Alignment Activity:
-	Test band: n28
-	Number of test cases: 3 PADs
-	Operation mode: NR Standalone (SA)
-	Use scenario: Free space
4.	Test results submission:
-	Use the same worksheet template in R4-2316308 to submit the measurement results
-	The measurement results should be submitted to RAN4 by anonymous approach (the UE model shall not be disclosed publicly)
-	Results shall not be shared between labs before submitting to RAN4 meetings or sharing in the RAN4 reflector. Comparison and lab alignment analysis should only be done in RAN4 meetings/discussions
5.	Lab alignment criteria:
-	The pass/fail criteria are defined as the maximum deviation between the measurement result and the reference value
-	The reference value will be derived based on the averaging approach (linear average in dBm) of lab alignment data pool from ≥ 3 labs
-	Apparent outliers (if identified) will not be considered in the average process for reference value. The PAD measurement result deviates over 1.5*preliminary MU (i.e., 4.55dB) from all the other labs’ results should be identified as apparent outlier.
-	Pass/fail limit for lab alignment should be defined as X*preliminary MU (X is TBD) as baseline.
6.	Volunteer lab procedures:
-	PAD delivery scheme: Decide PAD delivery scheme after all the volunteer labs and PADs information being confirmed.
-	PAD measurement time in each volunteer lab: finalize PAD measurement within [7] workdays, and deliver to the next lab ASAP with PAD delivery In/Out information shared in email-reflector.

content.title: 8	Lab alignment of FR2 MIMO OTA

subsections.title: 8.1	Framework
subsections.text_content:
This clause defines the working procedure on how to proceed the FR2 MIMO OTA lab alignment campaign. The purpose of lab alignment activity is to ensure there is no unexpected lab deviation and establish full trust and confidence on the measurement data pool for specifying FR2 MIMO OTA performance requirements.
1.	Test labs are invited to participate in the lab alignment activity, the following conditions should be fulfilled:
-	At least 3 participating labs are required.
-	Participating labs shall complete channel model validation.
-	Participating labs should have sufficient test resource to provide on-time measurement results without delay.
-	Each lab should finalize PAD measurement within 10 workdays, and deliver to the next lab in the same country ASAP with PAD In/Out information shared via email-reflector; otherwise, labs in the same country should equally share the period for testing the PADs.
2.	Test methodology:
-	Test plan: 3GPP TS 38.151
3.	Test cases for Lab Alignment Activity:
-	Test band: n261 (for PADs that support n261), n257 (for the PAD that does not support n261)
-	Number of test cases: 2~4 PADs per-band
-	Operation mode: NR Non-Standalone (NSA) is preferred and SA is not precluded, and should be mapped with the measurement results submission.
-	Power class: PC3
4.	Test results submission:
-	Use the same worksheet template in R4-2308740 to submit the measurement results
-	The measurement results should be submitted to RAN4 by anonymous approach (the UE model shall not be disclosed publicly)
-	Results shall not be shared between labs before submitting to RAN4 meetings or sharing in the RAN4 reflector. Comparison and lab alignment analysis should only be done in RAN4 meetings/discussions
5.	Lab alignment criteria:
-	The pass/fail criteria are defined as the maximum deviation between the MASC measurement result and the reference value
-	The reference value is derived based on the per-band averaging approach of lab alignment data pool from ≥ 3 labs, whether apparent outliers will be considered in averaging process, or not, is FFS
-	Pass/fail limit for lab alignment should be derived from the preliminary MU value. Adopt [0.5-1]*preliminary MU as starting point and further check after the FR2 MU is decided and some PAD measurement results are available.
